Rather than a "main" unit test method I would prefer if each of these methods were their own unit test.
I guess this would be ok if each of these tests rely on the state left by a prior state. If that is not the case please add a @Test annotation to each of these test methods.

timeline.message:
[neohub] adopted suggestions from code review by @cpmeister

Signed-off-by: Andrew Fiddian-Green <software@whitebear.ch>

timeline.bodyText: If the api is offline shouldn't that cause the thing to go offline as well?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: It does in fact cause the thing status to go offline -- this happens when the next poll calls fromNeoHubGetDeviceData() which fails with an exception that is caught on lines 268..270 (note: I intentionally don't change thing status in selectApi() to avoid unnecessarily doing the same thing in several places)
replies.author: andrewfg

timeline.bodyText: should probably still log this as debug or trace.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: same here

timeline.message:
[neohub] adopted suggestions mad in code review by @cpmeister

Signed-off-by: Andrew Fiddian-Green <software@whitebear.ch>

timeline.bodyText: It seems like you are trying to implement an expiring cache, so why not try using openhab's ExpiringCache class?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: No, it’s not really a cache. I will explain it below...
replies.author: andrewfg

timeline.bodyText: I've spent a lot of time trying to figure out how all this expiration stuff works and frankly I think it is too complicated for a variety of reasons. One of the reasons is that you are modifying handler state in your getter methods. I don't think this logic belongs here and instead should be moved to the caller of this method.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
The hub provides two sorts of data: the fast changing live data from devices, and the slow changing settings from users. The fast changing data is called Info in the old Api and LiveData in the new Api. And the slow changing data is called DCB (old) and System (new). The fast changing data is polled (according to pollInterval) every 60 seconds. And the slow changing data is read less frequently. In the new Api, the LiveData includes a time stamp tag on the System data so the data can be automatically read (only) when the time stamp changes (systemDirty). However in the old Api the Info does not include such a time stamp, so instead the binding has to “assume” that the data is dirty from time to time, which it does every one hour (even if probably the data has not changed).
Perhaps there is a better way to handle the polling of the slow changing data? In particular with the old Api? Do you have some suggestions?
You are partly right about the split of logic between the handler and the getters; the getters do indeed read the actual data, but only the handler knows the context about what changed (time stamp tag) since the getter was last called. Nevertheless I will see if I can shift some of the logic to the getters whilst still keeping the context in the handler.
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText: Hmm. I have been thinking some more about this. And I have made some changes about how the timestamps are checked (if any), and how systemData is updated. I hope it is Ok with you.
replies.author: andrewfg

timeline.bodyText: I don't know why you are checking systemDataDirty here. It would be better to push the burden of checking systemDataDirty on the caller.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: But please note that the old Api callRead_DCB and new Api call Get_System are 99% the same code, so the same class is used as a getter for each. The systemDirty and refresh logic is different between old and new but the actual JSON payload is the same..
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText: Incorporated in the above mentioned changes..
replies.author: andrewfg

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't this log every hour then regardless of if the unit changed or not? If you going to log it that frequently I'd prefer if you changed this to debug.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: This should be wrapped in a check if (newTemperatureUnit != oldTemperatureUnit) {} so this would only be logged on binding start up, of when the user actually changes settings from Fahrenheit to Celsius (which is probably never).
replies.author: andrewfg

timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: I am not sure I understand you. On one hand I am checking if devices is null and on the other hand I am checking if it is empty..
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText: The QoS measurement is a percentage of devices that are actually online in the RF mesh, divided by devices that have been configured in the hub. Obviously if there are zero devices configured in the hub, this would result in a divide-by-zero exception, so in that special case, we return UNDEF instead.
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText: Ah. Ok. I see my error now. Sorry for the confusion.
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText:
At that point you might as well cancel the fastPollingScheduler since it won't do anything at that point.

Good point. Note: as [siemensrds] uses the same code, I shall need to open yet another PR to fix this on that binding. Sorry for that :(

Also, no point in using AtomicInteger if you aren't going to make the changes atomic.

Sorry but I don't understand what you are saying here. But I think I can use fastPollingCallsToGo-- anyway since (in Java) that is in any case an atomic operation. Or??
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText:
use fastPollingCallsToGo-- anyway since (in Java) that is in any case an atomic operation. Or??

To answer my own question: Nope!
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText:
^^
Please ignore everything I have said above!
I fundamentally do NOT agree with your initial suggestion to cancel the thread!
The fastPollingScheduler is created in initialize() and cancelled & destroyed in dispose(). For the interim time between initialize() and dispose() the thread is always regularly being executed. In its execute method, if fastPollingCallsToGo > 0 the method will actually do something, otherwise the method will simply short circuit.
So the decision whether fastPollingScheduler will do anything depends on the value of fastPollingCallsToGo  -- this value is a) decremented by one every time that lazyPollingScheduler executes, and b) set back to a positive value any time that the method startFastPollingBurst() is called. It is an interplay between the two methods: one is saying that fewer future calls are needed, whereas the other is saying that more future calls are required.
So I would like to stick with my code as designed. But if you insist to create / cancel / destroy fastPollingScheduler every time that it is needed, it would be a major architecture change which goes way beyond the few changes you proposed above...
replies.author: andrewfg

replies.bodyText: Well what you have designed works, and if you think it would be too much effort to change it then you can keep it as is.
replies.author: cpmeister
